title: Friday, 29th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hello! Welcome. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's thing with the things and things.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
Soundbuy Morning............
Alchemy30 morning

It's Friday, it's a bit monodirectional and there's very little corporate around ....

BE11:05am

...... so let's start with a quiz.

Soundbuy Market rather jiggy......
Paper Chase Hullo.
Soundbuy Prize?
Excel Developer @BE: Arts and Literature please

This Trust is suitable for all investors seeking a fund that aims to deliver growth with a long investment time horizon as the core or a component of a portfolio of investments.

Stateless Morning
Tom Dalgleish Swiss Central Bank
11:11 am

Okay, so I'm not a financial adviser, but I'm going to suggest that you might look for a wee bit more diversification in your core investments for a long investment time horizon.

Tom Dalgleish This Trust WAS suitable for all investors seeking a fund that aims to deliver growth with a long investment time horizon...............
BE11:11am

Anyway, I mention that apropos of nothing whatsoever. Let's get on.

Mr Diamond @BE. also saw they increased the gearing on that recently...
Soundbuy Conservative sounding fund.............
undefined

11:12 am

Okay, so the FTSE's up because the usual. Trade war something something.

BE11:13am

(@Paper Chase: no idea.)

Dec69 - Skeptic I'm starting a fund to invest in crap, estimated returns YOY are somewhere between negative and positive.
Soundbuy @Dec69 - I'm in............
BE11:14am

In terms of interesting stuff, the stand-out is probably Allianz.

Grouchmonkey @Dec69 woodford beat you to it
Dec69 - Skeptic Put the house on it, the grandmother, you name it.
Tom Dalgleish ..............Jun 5, 2018 - The board of the £7.3bn Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust has borrowed a further £170m to increase its gearing facilities amid scope for ...
Dec69 - Skeptic Drat @GrtouchMonkey, I need more conviction
Manxish @Grouch - haha
11:14 am
BE11:15am

Allianz has been an obsession for the market for about six months.

BE11:15am

Helped along by stories like this: https://www.bloomb...ps-market-guessing

BE11:15am

Europe’s largest insurer, Allianz SE, is in the early stages of evaluating a variety of potential acquisition targets as deal-hungry Chief Executive Officer Oliver Baete scans the market for growth, people with knowledge of the matter said. Those on the list range from Switzerland’s Zurich Insurance Group AG and the U.K.’s RSA Insurance Group Plc to Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. in the U.S. or, going further afield, assets in China, they said.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

............ which has been repeated in various forms by lots of other media.

Dec69 - Skeptic I've been tracking a UK company that 50% of its receivables appear to be in court, unpaid, near 12 months after due, but the company's financials appear to find the debt current. Very odd. Yeap 50%
hornblower anyone following Countrywide train wreck? down 50% in a week. needs to raise £125m, mkt cap £90m debt £200m hmm
nichoman isn't there some hot new insur tech thing they could buy for a few bil?
BE11:16am

Now, what happened yesterday was Allianz Insider

BE11:17am

In Munich. And, unusually, management had some comments on the above speculation.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's JP Morgan to summarise.

BE11:17am

Allianz said they have not tasked any investment bank to look at
a large deal on their behalf. They also said they are not talking to any of the companies mentioned in articles recently including those companies cited in the Bloomberg article from 19 June.

Tom Dalgleish Dec69, if said co is plainting for that money it would have to believe it current
BE11:18am

(I think the June 19 article was a comment thing by Chris Hughes of Bloomberg Opinion, so a tad unfair to highlight that one.)

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Otherwise, it's a lot of retreading old rules.

nichoman if i was a buy and hold investor in Scottish mortgage i think i'd want to see a bit more old skool stuff in there ...eg a bit of oil, tobacco..in case their view of a tech enabled utopia doesn't come to pass
Dec69 - Skeptic @Tom, I'd agree if said clients aren't near broke with little in the form of assets.
BE11:19am

 Deal criteria 1: is return on investment. Any deal must at least meet the
cost of capital of the Allianz group, plus an appropriate risk premium.
Allianz use an 8pct cost of capital, which given the group's 25pct leverage is equivalent to 9pct cost of equity. The appropriate risk premium would vary between zero for a German in market consolidation to 2pct for a deal in an emerging market.
 Deal criteria 2: is nonlife. Allianz has no appetite for life insurance
operations.
 Deal criteria 3: Allianz will only pay a deal premium if it is within its 9%
plus hurdle return on investment and if it is funded by synergies.

wayneJ @Dec69 - are the receivables from retail customers? I am looking at one where this is an 'issue'
BE11:19am

Bolt-ons remain possible. But not terribly big ones.

Dec69 - Skeptic @WayneJ yes, and it stinks, both commercial and retail.
Tom Dalgleish Dec69, I've seen worse
wayneJ And the CEO has some 'history' of financial management - in the same way as rats leaving sinking ships
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Allianz highlighted its success with the LV deal announced last year, where it is acquiring control of the largest direct nonlife insurer in the UK at a relatively attractive valuation. The valuation for the deal is less than the current valuation of the larger listed direct nonlife insurers in the UK. However, we believe Allianz’s strong cash flow means it can continue with buybacks too, and we forecast €1bn pa unchanged.

Dec69 - Skeptic for a multi-billion£ Mkt Cap, I'm shocked, surprised, disappointed the short interest is so low.
BE11:21am

From there, I guess we have to observe that US insurer Assurant has a current market cap of $6.56bn.

hornblower Dec69 - going to share?
chad_john @BE - any World Cup prediction updates?
Dec69 - Skeptic @Chad I'm offski to the final. That's all I know
Soundbuy Name and shame............gawn gawn..................
Dec69 - Skeptic its unfair, I'm sure @BE hasn't got a legal eagle sat next to him and he'll beat me with the zapper!
chad_john not if it stands up, Dec69, which it will if it's in the courts as you say.
Excel Developer Does anyone like Malta? Lord Ashcroft (Brexiter) is keen on this EU member state.
Dec69 - Skeptic @Excel, I was there the other day.
Excel Developer https://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2018/06/lord-ashcroft-special-report-malta-makes-a-strong-case-to-host-the-eu-outposts-of-british-companies-after-brexit.html
BE11:24am

Bandit10 types and Spanish guys on Twitter have been pushing Assurant for weeks. And, while nothing's certain, recent comments from Allianz don't seem to do their case any good.

Grouchmonkey Lots of HNWI like Malta. It is very accommodating
11:24 am
undefined
Dec69 - Skeptic Can highly recommend Lore & Fitch, eat on the balcony though
nichoman IWG deadline is today....shares not doing much
Dec69 - Skeptic Maybe wework will buy 'em @Nichoman....
BE11:26am

(@nichoman: I'll bet dollars to doughnuts for an extension.)

BE11:26am

Okay, so what else we got?

Stateless @BE Allianz took a bit of Liverpool friendly soc a while back I think, might do the rest.

Excel Developer @Dec69 - cuisine looks similar to Italy.

alewis2005 final night of the shakespeare dinner/theatre event that I've been flogging - it's v good
11:27 am

No immediate thoughts on Ashcroft's offshore trolling, except to agree that Malta's quite nice.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Excel, I'd say the cuisine is better,. @Chad, rotation out of ProSeibenSat to ITV was my understanding.

Elementis ..... okay. Let's do that.

BE11:28am

It's buying a maker of talc additives from PE.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

For $600m, part funded with a rights issue.

BE11:29am

The key concern here is price, which is extremely high.

chad_john aha, thanks
BE11:30am

I'd also note, though, that talc's quite interesting.

Dec69 - Skeptic I learned something about talcum from my barber the other day, its brilliant for shaving rash. (Call it a slow thought process for me)
11:30 am
BE11:31am

You might've been following the progress of cases against J&J and Imerys in the US.

Maverick Elvis
alewis2005 General question - will the current shortage of CO2 have any lasting effect on any company?
Grouchmonkey @BE nope. Do you have a link to any sort of a background on the litigation?
BE11:32am

Imerys agreed to settle a bunch of cases earlier this month with people who accused J&J of selling baby powder tainted with talc that had asbestos traces.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Alewis, is there a listed Chicken Processor?
Maverick Tyson
chad_john alewis2005 - it's a bubbled storm in a teacup, IMO.
BE11:32am

Imerys, the talc supplier, denies that.

chad_john Can't see any material impact to anyone
Dec69 - Skeptic @GrouchMonkey its on PACER.
Grouchmonkey Thanks
Sails I thought we were pumping out megatonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere with our terrible fossil fuels and cow farts. How can there possibly be a shortage?
Paper Chase @sails Because you can't go around with a tea strainer catching the stuff
11:33 am
BE11:33am

There was also a New Jersey case earlier in the year where a jury ruled against Imerys and in favour of a chap with, I think, melanoma. Imerys is appealing.

Sails perhaps cow farts are methane, but anyway
Manxish cow farts are methane
Tom Dalgleish @BE that's why nobody should live near a blast furnace
Dec69 - Skeptic @Sails, the efficiency of processing, means if we extracted from the atmosphere, then it would add near 21% to the price of drinks as a conservative estimate and make certain production facilities economical bust.
BE11:34am

Anyway, I note all this as a sidebar. The more important thing here is that Elementis is paying a lot for this thing.

BE11:34am

Here's Caz.

Sails temporary shortage surely - Air Products and other 'producers' to the rescue?
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Mondo has good profitability with ~25% EBITDA margin and revenue of €122m in 2017. The implied multiple is 17x ‘17A EV/EBITDA and 13.1x YTD run-rate EBITDA including modest synergies with implied EBITDA accretion of ~25% on current standalone Elementis Bloomberg consensus. Though, EPS accretion will be much lower due to new debt and equity to be issued.

Tom Dalgleish Mesothelioma
BE11:35am

Company notes good mid-term growth potential of ~7% CAGR in markets ex. the paper business, which is structurally declining and represented ~20% of 2017 sales. A few structural growth drivers notes include the use of talc additives in plastics for light weighting applications as well as in a few other applications like life sciences. There will likely be some synergies in terms of material exposure to the Coatings market of both companies as well as from sharing of best practices given that Elementis also owns Hectorite mine in the US. In our view, the key investor concern will likely be on the acquisition multiple, which appears high relatively to a few peers of Mondo (e.g. Imerys, Mineral Technologies) – though these peers have broader exposure to other minerals/products. Further, structural headwinds in the Paper market (~20% of Mondo’s current sales) will likely present some ongoing headwind to growth in the mid-term and there is some literature suggesting talc additives might not be well suited for water-based paints which might potentially be a headwind to sales in Mondo’s coatings business.

Dec69 - Skeptic The MONDO deal actually looks "ok" not exciting but OK
Sails sheesh, being taken literally. That'll teach me
BE11:35am

(@Tom: bless you.)

Sails Mesothelioma, the illness that bankrupted a thousand Names

undefined

wayneJ The issue with analysts' EV/ EBITDA calculations is whether they include any contingent liabilities
Manxish Much lower bar for establishing negligence in Mesothelioma cases though, every cloud and all that...

Sails @Tom Dalgleish it looks like Buffett bought the asbestos liabilities tail - https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/insurance/8463871/How-asbestos-brought-Lloyds-of-London-to-its-knees-in-the-90s.html

11:40 am

Raising PO to 225p and EPS 18-20E by 1-3% Recent channel checks suggest slight upside risk to cons. ad growth expectations. Reinvestment risks seem largely priced in. ITV also fits well with the ongoing M&A theme in Media & Entertainment, thanks to the strength of its Studio business.

chad_john Thanks BE
BE11:41am

That's the blipvert take.

Excel Developer Hey, members of EFTA have freedom of movement with Malta. https://anyworkanywhere.com/visas_mt.html

Would it be a bit weird if Ian Griffiths decided to quit if he thought a bid was on the way? Or would that be totally rational? Dunno.

11:42 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Elsewhere among sellside ......

BE11:42am

There's Hunting.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

This is all about Permian Basin takeaway capacity ....

BE11:43am

...... which is exactly what it sounds like. The pipes to take the oil from the basin to somewhere else that's not the basin.

Excel Developer I keep hearing the Permian Basin, why don;t they just say Texas, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permian_Basin_(North_America)
BE11:44am

Morgan Stanley saying pipeline capacity won't be in place until the back half of next year so well completion is likely to slow down a bit.

alewis2005 ooh I learned about the Permian Basin thanks to reading Friday Night Lights
11:45 am
BE11:45am

(@Excel: because it's also in New Mexico?)

alewis2005 v interesting book about high school football in Odessa, Texas
alewis2005 more of a social commentary, really
BE11:45am

And Hunting is priced for recovery, not slowdown. So, overweight to underweight. target back to 920p.

BE11:45am

The market has become concerned about the ability of Permian E&Ps to execute production plans for 2H18 and 1H19, on the back of takeaway constraints. With new pipeline infrastructure not coming online until 2H19, we think Hunting's recovery story risks being delayed as completions slow down.

Excel Developer haha
wayneJ The issue re capacity has been going on for nearly 2 years - if anything it is now that the debottlenecking and additional capacity is coming on board.
wayneJ Also the longer wells are left the more pumping of water etc u have to do before going into production.
11:46 am
BE11:46am

While completions could rise as takeaway capacity comes online late 2019, we see little room for this issue to be resolved near term given current tightness in truck and rail transportation.

BE11:47am

We remain convinced on the potential for Titan to reach new peaks, yet this may take longer to materialise. With less momentum we don't think the stock will re-rate as much, thus we lower our target multiple to 8.0x 2020 EBITDA from 10.0x before, similar to the de-rating of US peers.

wayneJ The FERC ruling has also added confusion and may have delayed some pipelines
BE11:48am

Note the US rig count has been flatlining this month. Small decline last week I think.

wayneJ But the FERC pipeline ruling has to be offset against the tax cuts and depreciation rates. Potentially net net the E&P economics to get moving has changed.
wayneJ @BE the rig count is misleading on a yoy basis due to a change in how rigs are used - more vertical stacking / longer horizontals and better utilisation
11:49 am
BE11:50am

You also have lots of reports that Halliburton and Gardner Denver are pushing aggressively, and that well operators are choosing to bring old equipment out of retirement.

Forester Forget about oil and CO2, I have had to dig a further foot down my well on my allotment!

(@wayneJ: the data does break down those categories doesn't it?)

Readthrough here for Weir, mostly.

undefined
wayneJ The bringing of old kit has been going on since Spring 2017. (Winter 2016 - 2017 was particularly unusual as well - surface water froze in the Permian but also made it easier to preposition kit).
Maverick BREAKING - IWG says Starwood and TDR have secured bid deadline extension to July 21st
wayneJ @AM - if you look in the data that is all there - the key parameter to monitor is DUCs (drilled but UnCompleted)
BE11:52am

So, what else do we have? It's the last day of the first half.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

... and that dollars-to-doughnuts bet I made earlier is paying out.

BE11:53am

https://www.invest...e-under-rule-2-6-c-201806291145490826T

BE11:53am

Pursuant to the announcement dated 8 June 2018, each of Starwood and TDR were required, by not later than 5.00 p.m. on 29 June 2018, to either announce a firm intention to make an offer for the Company in accordance with Rule 2.7 of the Code or announce that it did not intend to make an offer, in which case the announcement would have been treated as a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Code applied.

In accordance with Rule 2.6(c) of the Code, the Board of IWG requested that the Panel on Takeovers and Mergers (the "Panel") extend the deadline referred to above with respect to these parties. Accordingly, an extension has been granted by the Panel and each of Starwood and TDR must, by no later than 5.00 p.m. on 21 July 2018, either announce a firm intention to make an offer for IWG in accordance with Rule 2.7 of the Code or announce that it does not intend to make an offer, in which case the announcement will be treated as a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Code applies.

This deadline will only be extended with the consent of the Panel.

A further announcement will be made when appropriate. There can be no certainty that any offer will be made for the Company, nor as to the terms on which any offer might be made.

A. M. @wayneJ: thanks, will have a look (I mainly see it via Kemp).

wayneJ One of the things being missed is that the existing pump fleet (including resting kit) has been brought back rather aggressively.
wayneJ A lot of analysts are missing the wear on that kit and how when it is running hot (ie lots of demand) maintenance is postponed.
cheeckychappy Any update on your Bunge story from last week Brycey?
wayneJ Also the longer laterals and increased frack stages are impacting pump utilisation. The pipeline issue has stopped an extreme spike but as the pipeline issue resolves then the pumps are going to be worn out and there will be a wave of new pumps needed

(@cheeckychappy: nope! Not a thing.)

Knights Group. Up 20% live.

BE11:57am

"one of the UK’s fastest growing regional legal and professional services businesses"

wayneJ A simple exercise - imagine u had a 0.5 mile long lateral and you did 2-3 frack stages - and now you have 3 mile laterals and 20 frack stages. But u avoid having to spend 3 days moving pumps between wells. What is the utilisation and wear on the pumps.....just asking for a friend....

BE11:59am

Knights is a fast-growing, regional legal and professional services business, ranked within the UK top 100 largest law firms by revenue. Knights was one of the first law firms in the UK to move from the traditional partnership model to a corporate structure in 2012 and has since grown rapidly. Knights has specialists in all of the key areas of corporate and commercial law so that it can offer end-to-end support to businesses of all sizes and in all sectors. The Company’s main focus is on the UK’s secondary regional markets, offering ‘big city’ quality expertise from a regional cost base. Currently, Knights operates from six offices located in Cheltenham, Chester, Derby, Newcastle-Under-Lyme, Manchester, Wilmslow, Chester, Derby, Cheltenham and Oxford and Wilmslow with a seventh office in Manchester added today with the acquisition of Turner Parkinson LLP which completes on Admission.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Listed law firms .... remind me, they've been a great success, right?

wayneJ @Tom Dalgleish - spivs guide to having a gusher - frack a well and then cap it and leave it for 6 - 9 months for the oil to accumulate ...... then see how much oil u get in the first hour or first 24 hours and report that to the street........anyone serious looks at the 30 day or stabilised output - not the first few hours....

A. M. (if anything, a gusher shows that the operator got its numbers wrong..)
